content.text: Place the load \(\mathbf{X}\) on the rule so that its centre is at \(d = 5.0 \text{cm}\) from the zero end of the rule as shown in Fig. 1.1. Record the value of \(d\) in Table 1.1
Adjust the position of the rule so that it is as near as possible to being balanced, with the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the right of the pivot
Measure, and record in the table, the distance \(x\) from the centre of the load \(\mathbf{X}\) to the pivot
Measure, and record in the table, the distance \(y\) from the pivot to the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule
Repeat the steps (i)â€“(iv) using \(d\) values of \(10.0 \text{cm}\), \(15.0 \text{cm}\), \(20.0 \text{cm}\) and \(25.0 \text{cm}\)
Plot the graph of \(y / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(x / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). You do not need to include origin (0,0) on your graph
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the weight \(W\) of the metre rule using the equation \(W = \frac{L}{G}\), where \(L = 1.0 \text{N}\)
In this experiment, you will determine the weight of a metre rule
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 1.1
You are provided with a 1.0 N load, labelled \(\mathbf{X}\)
Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into the beaker labelled \(\mathbf{A}\)
Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\) of the water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{c}} =\)
Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\) of the hot water supplied
\(\theta_{\mathrm{h}} =\)
Add \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water to the water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\)
Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) of the mixture of hot and cold water
\(\theta_{\mathrm{m}} =\)
State two precautions that you took to ensure the reliability of your value of the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\)
Calculate \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\), the average of \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\)
average \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}} =\)   .........
Empty the water from beaker \(\mathbf{A}\)
Repeat the steps (a)(i), (ii), (iii) and (v) using \(130 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water and \(130 \text{cm}^3\) hot water
A student suggests that the temperature of the mixture \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) should be the average of \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\)
State whether your experimental results support this suggestion and justify your statement by reference to your results
statement
justification

Suggest a practical reason in this experiment for the temperature of the mixture \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) being different from the average value \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\), even when the precautions you have stated in (a)(iv) have been taken
Suggest a modification to the experiment which should reduce the difference between \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\)
In this experiment, you will investigate temperature changes when hot water and cold are mixed
You are provided with a supply of hot water and a supply of cold (room temperature) water
Switch on. Record the current \(I_{\mathrm{A}}\) in the circuit
Switch off
Change the position of the ammeter to the position marked \(\mathbf{B}\) on Fig. 3.1. Switch on. Record the current \(I_{\mathrm{B}}\) in the circuit
Switch off
Change the position of the ammeter to the position marked \(\mathbf{C}\) on Fig. 3.1. Switch on. Record the current \(I_{\mathrm{C}}\) in the circuit
Switch off
Change the position of the ammeter to the position marked \(\mathbf{D}\) on Fig. 3.1. Switch on. Record the current \(I_{\mathrm{D}}\) in the circuit
Switch off
Calculate \(I_{\mathrm{B}} + I_{\mathrm{C}}\)
IB+ IC =
State whether your experimental results support the theory and justify your statement by reference to your results
statement
justification
Theory suggests that \(I_{\mathrm{A}} = I_{\mathrm{B}} + I_{\mathrm{C}}\) and \(I_{\mathrm{D}} = I_{\mathrm{B}} + I_{\mathrm{C}}\)
Connect the voltmeter so that it measures the potential difference \(V\) across the combination of the three resistors. Record the potential difference \(V.\)
V =
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the combination of the three resistors using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
On Fig. 3.1, draw in the voltmeter connected as described in (c)(i) using the standard symbol for a voltmeter
In this experiment, you will investigate the current in resistors in a circuit
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1. The circuit is set up for you
Fig. 3.1

Draw a line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long near the middle of the ray trace sheet. Label the line \(\mathbf{MR}\). Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\)

Draw a line \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\) to the normal below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\). Record the angle of incidence \(i\) in Table 4.1
Place the mirror, with its reflecting face vertical, on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\). The mirror has a line drawn on it. One end of this line must be at point \(\mathbf{B}\)
Place a pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) at \(\mathbf{A}\)
View the line on the mirror and the image of pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) from the direction indicate

eye in Fig. 4.1. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) some distance apart so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) , \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) image of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) , and the line on the mirror all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the
positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\)
Remove the pins and the mirror and draw in the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\). Continue the line until it meets the normal
Measure, and record in the table, the angle of reflection \(r\) between the normal and the line passing through \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\)
Draw a line from \(\mathbf{A}\) to \(\mathbf{C}\). Measure, and record in the table, the angle of incidence \(i\) between line \(\mathbf{AC}\) and the normal
(j) Place the mirror, with its reflecting face vertical, on the line \(\mathbf{M}_1\mathbf{R}_1\). One end of the line on the mirror must be at point \(\mathbf{C}\)
(k) Repeat the steps \((\mathbf{d}) - (\mathbf{g})\)

(l) In spite of carrying out this experiment with reasonable care, it is possible that the values of the angle of reflection \(r\) will not be exactly the same as the values obtained from theory. Suggest two possible causes of this inaccuracy
**Tie in your ray trace sheet between pages 10 and 11.**

Draw a line parallel to \(\mathbf{MR}\) and \(2\mathrm{cm}\) above it. Label the line \(\mathbf{M}_1\mathbf{R}_1\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses the line with the letter \(\mathbf{C}\)
In this experiment, you will investigate the reflection of light by a plane mirror
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 4.1
